Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Neuropeptide Y in Fat Deposition in Birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neuropeptide Y is a neurotransmitter, but also functions as a hormone to affect other organs such as adipose tissue. It is one of the strongest stimuli of food intake in birds and mammals, and promotes fat storage in mammals. There is no information on the role of NPY in fat deposition in birds and mechanisms governing adipose accumulation in avian species are still unclear. Increased seasonal food intake and fat accumulation in birds and mammals (e.g., in preparation for migration and hibernation, respectively) are important for survival. Thus, a greater understanding of adipose development should provide novel insight into evolutionary adaptations for seasonal changes in body composition. Based on preliminary data from lean and fat birds showing differences in NPY and receptor gene expression in adipose tissue and differential food intake responses to NPY, it is hypothesized that NPY will affect fat formation and maintenance in birds and that these processes will be affected by both exogenous and adipose-derived NPY. A greater understanding of the physiological processes associated with fat deposition in birds has broad applications to all classes of vertebrates that undergo periodic acclimation to food shortage by adjusting appetite and energy storage in fat. The findings may also contribute to obesity research and potentially reduce healthcare costs.

This work has four main goals, using chickens as the model organism: 1) Characterize the avian adipose-hypothalamic NPY axis by quantifying the abundance of NPY and its receptors in adipose tissue and hypothalamus. 2) Understand the function of NPY in regulating development of fat cells. Approaches include evaluating effects of NPY treatment on pre-adipocyte proliferation and differentiation in an in-vitro fat culture system. 3) Determine if adipose-derived NPY plays a role in adipogenesis. NPY mRNA will be knocked-down in pre-adipocytes and effects on differentiation will be evaluated. 4) Elucidate the signaling pathway(s) responsible for NPY's effects on fat cells. Fat cells will be treated with NPY receptor sub-type-specific antagonists to demonstrate the mechanism through which NPY affects fat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project yielded transformative research findings that enhance our understanding of how birds form and maintain body fat, technical and professional training opportunities for graduate students and undergraduate researchers, outreach to the scientific community in the form of lectures, presentations at conferences, and publications, and novel tools for the research community.

Firstly, a chick primary cell culture platform was successfully established. This model can be widely adapted by other researchers to understand the factors that regulate preadipocyte (precursors to fat cells) proliferation and differentiation in birds, a critical facet of fat biology. Results of the research revealed for the first time in an avian species that appetite-regulating peptides (factors that act via the brain to affect hunger and feeding behavior) affect fat cell formation and lipid metabolism in birds, thus filling a gap in knowledge about cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in fat deposition in birds. Specifically, results demonstrated that neuropeptide Y (NPY), a potent hunger-stimulating factor, promotes fat cell development and lipid accumulation in avian abdominal fat. These effects are likely mediated through NPY receptor sub-type 2 (as this was the only receptor that was detected in preadipocytes) and involve transcriptional regulation of genes that encode transcription factors, metabolic enzymes, and a fatty acid binding protein, at various stages of cellular differentiation. The effects of NPY on fat may also involve recruitment of new precursor cells during differentiation.

Research efforts also culminated in the development of lentiviral particles expressing short-hairpin (sh) RNAs that target two chick NPY receptors, sub-types 1 and 2. These lentiviral particles are used to suppress expression of the receptors in tissues or cells of interest, thereby permitting the investigation of the role of the receptors in physiological processes. Such a tool does not exist in the research community and thus represents a significant advancement in the development of resources for the study of adipose tissue biology in birds. The research tools and knowledge generated from this project can be expanded and applied to other vertebrate models.

During the two-year award, a Master’s student, Steven Shipp, carried out this research and completed the degree program, defending and publishing the thesis in December of 2016. During the project, Steven published two refereed publications: 1) a review paper on the role of appetite-regulating peptides in adipose tissue physiology and 2) an original research article describing the effects of NPY on avian preadipocyte proliferation and differentiation. A Ph.D. student, Wei Zhang, defended the dissertation during the first year of this project and published findings in a refereed journal shortly thereafter. Results were presented at local (annual departmental research symposium) and national (Poultry Science Association meeting) conferences and used as discussion prompts in Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience, a course instructed by the PI. Steven mentored undergraduate researchers during the program, efforts that were rewarded by additional national and local research conference presentations and an original research article that is currently undergoing review.

In summary, this project resulted in novel research findings that advance our knowledge of avian adipose tissue physiology, new research tools that are available to other investigators for studying adipose tissue biology in birds, opportunities to educate diverse audiences, and enormous potential for growth beyond the scope of the funded research project. Currently, two Ph.D. students are conducting research that builds on the results of this project.
